{
  "article_text": [
    "extreme mass ratio binary ( emrb ) systems are typically comprised of a small compact object , such as a stellar black hole , orbiting a super - massive blackhole , and the gravitational radiation generated by such systems is potentially detectable by the lisa project .",
    "a number of approaches attempt to model the resulting gravitational waveforms , including effective one body formulations @xcite , effective field theory techniques @xcite , post - newtonian expansions @xcite , self - force effects @xcite , and different gauge choices @xcite . when including high - order effects or performing comparisons between techniques ,",
    "improved emrb modeling will increasingly require the identification and reduction of all error sources ( both numerical and systematic ) .    consider a small perturbation @xmath0 of a fixed background schwarzschild metric , where @xmath0 satisfies the linearized einstein equations .",
    "the metric perturbation @xmath0 describing an emrb can be reconstructed from a collection of scalar _ master functions _",
    "@xmath1 , each of which obeys a forced wave equation of the form ( with all multipole indices suppressed ) @xmath2 . \\end{split}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] the coordinates here are the areal radius @xmath3 , the regge ",
    "wheeler tortoise coordinate @xmath4 , and the time - dependent radial location @xmath5 of the smaller mass or  particle \" .",
    "@xmath6 is the mass parameter of the background solution , @xmath7 , and @xmath8 is either the regge - wheeler or zerilli potential ( explicit expressions for both are given in sec .",
    "[ sec : staticmastereqn ] ) .",
    "the _ distributional _",
    "inhomogeneity on the right  hand side of involves dirac delta functions , as well as the ordinary functions @xmath9 and @xmath10 . for all possible choices of the master function , @xmath9 and @xmath10",
    "are listed in , for example , in refs .",
    "@xcite . here",
    "it suffices to note that their evaluation requires knowledge of the particle s four - velocity @xmath11 , orbital energy and angular momentum parameters ( @xmath12 , @xmath13 ) , and equatorial location @xmath14 . in the model we study , integration of the geodesic equations",
    "determines the timelike particle trajectory @xmath15 in the equatorial plane @xmath16 .",
    "@xcite    one approach for computing emrb waveforms is to numerically solve eq .",
    "( [ eq : genericwaveeq ] ) as a time - domain initial value problem with prescribed initial data .",
    "the exact initial data for generic point - particle trajectories is non - trivial , and the most common choice is therefore to set both @xmath1 and its time derivative to zero .",
    "( see refs .",
    "@xcite for the construction of more realistic data . )",
    "inspection of ( [ eq : genericwaveeq ] ) shows that trivial data is inconsistent with the jump conditions stemming from the delta function terms in the inhomogeneity . as a result ,",
    "trivial data results in an impulsive ( i.  e.  discontinuous in time ) start - up .",
    "this paper addresses the main question of if , and when , a _ physical _",
    "solution eventually emerges from such trivial initial data .",
    "ideally , we would have both the correct source terms and initial conditions . without the exact initial data , we consider modifying the source terms such that they are consistent with the choice of trivial initial data .",
    "precisely , the source terms are  switched on \" smoothly via the following prescription : @xmath17 & & \\text{for } t_0\\leq t \\leq t_0+\\tau\\\\ 1 & & \\text{for } t > t_0+\\tau , \\end{array}\\right . \\end{split}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] and the same for @xmath18 .",
    "typically , the initial time @xmath19 , and the timescale @xmath20 is much shorter than the final time of the run . choosing suitable @xmath20 and @xmath21 , one achieves smooth and consistent start - up to machine precision .    to appreciate some of the issues associated with the main question above ,",
    "consider a particle in a fixed circular orbit .",
    "the energy @xmath22 and angular momentum @xmath23 luminosities for gravitational waves are then constant in time and obey the relation @xmath24 , where @xmath25 is the angular velocity of the particle . however , verification of this relationship is limited by a finite computational domain , leading to an @xmath26 error ( see ref .",
    "@xcite for a recent suggestion towards overcoming this limitation ) .",
    "therefore , numerical verification of @xmath24 is a useful diagnostic only in the distant wave - zone . in the near - zone",
    "we might also test  @xmath24 \" , now constructing the luminosities with self - force quantities via ( [ eq : el_evolve ] ) below ; however , because @xmath1 is discontinuous at the particle location , self - force measurements will involve large errors unless due care is taken . for generic quasi - periodic orbits , selection of a meaningful set of diagnostics is not straightforward . in particular , we can neither infer steady - state behavior throughout the computational domain , nor claim we have a solution which solves the hypothetical  true \" initial value boundary problem .",
    "these difficulties are due to the inconsistent initial conditions .",
    "that is , we are really solving a problem different from the physical one . as a partial resolution of these issues , we examine a direct test condition which is necessary to claim that a physically correct solution has been achieved everywhere in the computational domain .",
    "this is a simple self - consistency condition relating the cunningham - price - moncrief ( cpm ) and regge - wheeler ( rw ) master functions .",
    "violations of this relationship are necessarily due to numerical errors and/or incorrect initial conditions",
    ".    we will refer to errors seeded by the initial conditions as  junk \" .",
    "one type of junk either propagates off the computational domain or decays away .",
    "we collectively refer to such junk radiation , junk quasi - normal ringing , and junk price tails as _ dynamical junk_. the key observation of this paper is that trivial initial conditions _ may _ also give rise to a static distributional junk solution @xmath27 , which we refer to as _",
    "jost junk_. in terms of the  schrdinger operator \" @xmath28 , a jost solution satisfies @xmath29 , with @xmath30 as @xmath31 @xcite . in this paper",
    ", we are exclusively interested in  zero - energy \" jost solutions for which @xmath32 , in which case @xmath33 does not behave exponentially at infinity ( see below ) .",
    "therefore , in what follows a jost function satisfies a  zero - energy \" , time - independent , schrdinger equation @xmath34 to the left and right of the particle , and , as it turns out , is discontinuous at the particle location .",
    "we find that @xmath27 has a non - negligible effect in the wave - zone , yet is often small enough to be buried into the @xmath26 error associated with a waveform  read - off \" in the far - field .",
    ".basic set of parameters for a numerical simulation .",
    "this set is not complete , but in what follows we often refer to these variables . for all our simulations @xmath35 , where the choice @xmath36 is equivalent to working with per - particle - mass perturbations @xmath37 .",
    "[ cols=\">,^ , < \" , ]     we will adopt trivial initial conditions throughout , but allow for modified  smoothed \" source terms according to the aforementioned description ( [ eq : smoothfandg ] ) .",
    "our chief goal is to study the properties of the numerical solutions computed with and without smoothed source terms , especially in the context of the jost solution . to carry out numerical simulations ,",
    "we have primarily used the nodal legendre discontinuous galerkin method described in ref .",
    "@xcite , and further details of this method will not be given here .",
    "in addition , some of our results have either been obtained or independently verified with a nodal chebyshev method ( similar to the one described in refs .",
    "@xcite ) , which also features multiple subdomains and upwinding .",
    "our nodal chebyshev method treats the jump discontinuities at the particle location in the same fashion as outlined in ref .",
    "@xcite for the nodal dg method .",
    "both our dg and chebyshev methods solve a first order system representing ( [ eq : genericwaveeq ] ) .",
    "namely ,    [ eq : firstordersys ] @xmath38 \\\\ & + v(r ) \\psi + j_1 \\delta(\\xi-\\xi_p ) \\end{split } \\\\",
    "\\partial_\\lambda \\phi & = \\partial_\\xi ( { \\beta}^\\xi \\phi ) - \\partial_\\xi \\pi   + j_2 \\delta(\\xi-\\xi_p),\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    where the time - space coordinates @xmath39 are adapted to the particle history ( the particle location @xmath40 remains fixed in this system ) .",
    "( [ eq : firstordersys]a ) defines @xmath41 , the variable does _ not _ hold in the sense of distributions .",
    "more precisely , in the case of circular orbits , our @xmath42 is @xmath43\\!\\big]}\\delta(x -x_p)$ ] . ]",
    "@xmath44 , and ref .",
    "@xcite relates the @xmath45dependent jump terms @xmath46 to the sources in ( [ eq : genericwaveeq ] ) .",
    "most of this paper considers circular orbits , for which @xmath47 , @xmath48 , and the shift vector @xmath49 .",
    "we often refer to the variables @xmath41 and @xmath42 below , and for circular orbits these are @xmath50 and @xmath51 , respectively . throughout the paper , we make reference to the parameters listed in table [ table : parameters ] .",
    "this paper is organized as follows .",
    "section [ sec : jostjunk ] focuses on the jost solution , from both empirical and analytical standpoints .",
    "here we present analytic formulas for jost solutions and compare them with numerical results .",
    "section [ sec : consequences ] considers several practical consequences of impulsive start - up for emrb modeling with circular orbits : violation of the axial consistency condition , contamination of waveform luminosities , and influence on self - force measurements .",
    "this section also gives a preliminary report on consequences for eccentric orbits .",
    "concluding remarks are given in sec .",
    "[ sec : conclusions ] , where we touch upon finite - difference methods while discussing the universality of our results .",
    "longer calculations appear in the appendix .",
    "to better explain the origin of the jost junk solution , we first consider a toy model : the ordinary 1 + 1 wave equation with distributional forcing .",
    "we then examine the jost solution for the master wave equations , with a forcing determined by a circular orbit .     on smoothing parameters .",
    "we have empirically determined that @xmath52 for an impulsive start - up , corresponding to @xmath53 at the leftmost point .",

    ", height=192 ]      for a fixed velocity @xmath58 obeying @xmath59 , we consider the model @xmath60 ref .",

    "@xmath62 is the usual relativistic factor . for this model ,",
    "junk radiation propagates off the computational domain with speeds @xmath63 . however , when numerically solving this equation subject to ( incorrect ) trivial initial conditions , we observe that the numerical solution no longer converges to the particular solution . for simulations involving ( [ eq : forced1p1 ] ) ,",

    "to better model the circular orbit scenario for emrbs , we have taken @xmath71 .    with the exact solution used to generate initial conditions at @xmath72 , the nodal dg method exhibits spectral convergence throughout the computational domain ( and for all fields with the wave equation treated as a first order system )",
    "however , with trivial initial conditions , only the corresponding numerical derivatives , @xmath73 and @xmath74 , converge to the correct values , whereas @xmath75 itself is off by a constant value on each subdomain .",
    "let us write @xmath76 where @xmath77 is the heaviside function and the exact solution from ( [ eqn:1p1_sol ] ) is @xmath78 we introduce the time - independent 1 + 1 jost junk solution @xmath79 in order to express the numerical solution as @xmath80 .",
    "we examine the dependence of @xmath81 on the smoothing parameters @xmath82 , defined analogously to those in ( [ eq : smoothfandg ] ) , but here introduced to smooth our toy source term @xmath83 .",
    "we restrict the parameter space by first choosing @xmath20 , and then finding the smallest @xmath21 such that @xmath84 $ ] is less than @xmath85 when @xmath72 and greater than @xmath86 when @xmath87 .",
    "these requirements ensure that the start - up phase is smooth to machine precision , while providing the most gradual rate at which the distributional source terms are turned - on .",
    "figure [ fig:1p1_constant_smoother ] shows that the troublesome constant term is arbitrarily well suppressed by the smoothing procedure .",
    "however , we find that the value of @xmath88 remains fixed when varying the timestep .",
    "the final run time for each data point in the plot is @xmath89 .",
    "no essential difference exists between the @xmath90 and @xmath91 cases , except that for the latter case we must ensure that the particle does not get too close to the boundary .",
    "let @xmath92 represent @xmath75 obtained with smoothing , and @xmath93 represent @xmath75 obtained without smoothing .",

    "to empirically verify that an impulsive start - up also leads to a jost solution in this setting , we will form and plot the expression ( [ eqn : empiricaljost ] ) , using the chebyshev method .",
    "later on , we will give analytic expressions for static jost solutions .",

    "we record the set of axial functions ,    [ eqn : axialvlvr ] @xmath125    where for gravitational perturbations the spin @xmath126 .",
    "evidently , up to transformations of the dependent and independent variables , the equation @xmath127 is the hypergeometric equation .",
    "the equation @xmath128 involves an extra regular singular point , and its normal form is a particular realization of the heun equation . nevertheless , by exploiting certain intertwining relations between the polar and axial master functions @xcite , we are likewise able to express @xmath129 in terms of the classical gauss - hypergeometric function @xmath130 .",
    "the appendix gives further details .        to complete our analytic expressions for the jost solutions , we still must determine @xmath112 and @xmath113 .",
    "our notation for a time ",
    "dependent jump is , for example , @xmath131\\!\\big]}(t ) & \\equiv \\lim_{\\epsilon \\rightarrow 0^+ } \\big [ \\psi(t , r_p(t)+\\epsilon)- \\psi(t , r_p(t)-\\epsilon)\\big ]   \\nonumber\\\\ & = \\lim_{\\epsilon \\rightarrow 0^+ } \\big [ \\psi(t , r_p+\\epsilon)- \\psi(t , r_p-\\epsilon)\\big ] , \\label{eq : jumpdefinition}\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] with the last equality holding for a circular orbit . as derived in ref .",
    "@xcite , for a circular orbit the analytical jump determined by eq .",
    "( [ eq : genericwaveeq ] ) is @xmath132\\!\\big]}(t ) & = \\frac{f(t , r_p)}{f_p},\\end{aligned}\\ ] ] where the subscript  p \" indicates evaluation at the particle location . for trivial initial data ( that is @xmath133 ) this jump will in general not be satisfied at @xmath72 . we find empirically that the jump in @xmath27 exactly cancels @xmath134\\!\\big]}(0)$ ] , while the jump in @xmath135 is zero .",

    "we have used nearly the same set - up as described for fig .",
    "[ fig : smooth_vs_imp_allfields_circ_cpm ] , but with the outer boundary @xmath141 and final time @xmath142 .",
    "we wish to examine the extent to which the right analytic jost solutions @xmath143 satisfy radiation boundary conditions based on laplace convolution @xcite , as these are boundary conditions adopted for our numerical simulations .",
    "unfortunately , for blackhole perturbations the issue would seem difficult to address analytically .",
    "therefore , we consider the analogous issue for the flatspace radial wave equation .    consider a flatspace multipole solution @xmath144 to the ordinary 3 + 1 wave equation , and assume the multipole is initially of compact support in radius @xmath3 .",
    "exact non - reflecting boundary conditions relative to a sufficiently large outer boundary radius @xmath145 then take the form @xcite @xmath146 here @xmath147 are the roots of the modified cylindrical bessel function @xmath148 , also known as macdonald s function . all @xmath149 lie in the left - half plane .",
    "moreover , the scaled roots @xmath150 accumulate on a fixed transcendental curve as @xmath109 grows @xcite , so the exponentials @xmath151 tend to decay more quickly in time @xmath152 for larger @xmath109 .    for the flatspace setting at hand ,",
    "the jost solution satisfies @xmath153 and two appropriate linearly independent solutions are the following : @xmath154 we therefore examine to what extent @xmath155 satisfies ( [ eq : nbc ] ) .",
    "straightforward calculation yields @xmath156 the function @xmath155 does not satisfy the non - reflecting condition ( [ eq : nbc ] ) ; however , the violation of ( [ eq : nbc ] ) decays exponentially fast . for blackhole perturbations",
    "we likewise expect that @xmath157 violates our radiation boundary conditions only by exponentially decaying terms , and have seen some evidence of this behavior in our numerical simulations .",
    "we have also observed persistent junk solutions when adopting the sommerfeld condition at the outer boundary @xmath145 along with impulsive start - up .",
    "we differentiate between two scenarios : the first involving a detector which is not in causal contact with the outer boundary @xmath145 during the simulation , and a second with the detector located at @xmath145 . for the first scenario ,",
    "the static junk solution which develops and persists around the detector is precisely @xmath33 .",
    "for the second , we also observe a persistent junk solution , but one which is distorted from @xmath33 in a boundary layer near @xmath145 .",
    "such distortion presumably arises since @xmath33 satisfies the outer sommerfeld condition only up to an @xmath158 error term .",
    "axial perturbations are described by either the cunningham - price - moncrief master function @xmath159 or the regge - wheeler master function @xmath160 .",
    "both solve the generic wave equation ( [ eq : genericwaveeq ] ) with potential ( [ eq : reggewheelerv ] ) .",
    "however , the wave equations for @xmath159 and @xmath160 have different distributional source terms @xcite . as shown in @xcite ,",
    "these master functions obey @xmath161 and we refer to this formula as the _ axial consistency condition_. for circular orbits this condition becomes @xmath162 , @xmath163 .",
    "we now numerically examine the extent to which the axial consistency condition is violated when the master functions @xmath164 are obtained with and without smoothing .            for all experiments we again enforce sommerfeld boundary conditions at the left physical boundary , and radiation outer boundary conditions on the right boundary .",
    "now our smoothing parameters are @xmath165 , @xmath166 , and @xmath167 .",

    "other parameters ( cf .  table [ table : parameters ] ) are @xmath169 , @xmath170 , @xmath171 , @xmath172 , @xmath173 , @xmath69 , and @xmath174 .",
    "we first plot @xmath175 at various times .",
    "the left panels in fig .",
    "[ fig : circular_rw_cpm_metericpert_smoother ] show results with smoothing .",
    "although the consistency condition is initially violated , the expression eventually relaxes to a small value once the dynamical junk has propagated off the domain .",
    "the right panels in fig .",
    "[ fig : circular_rw_cpm_metericpert_smoother ] show result without smoothing . even at late times violation in the axial consistency condition is now evident .",
    "the plots in fig .",
    "[ fig : l2error_vs_time_cirsmooth ] depict @xmath175 recorded as a time series at @xmath176 .",
    "the plot for smooth start - up indicates that quasinormal ringing and price decay tails characterize the late - stage dynamical junk , although this ringing is suppressed with more smoothing ( e.  g.  with @xmath57 , @xmath56 ) .",
    "the plot for impulsive start - up suggests that a static jost junk solution @xmath177 persists indefinitely ( @xmath178 should be unaffected by a similar jost solution in @xmath179 ) .      for a given @xmath180 multipole either read off at a finite radius or measured at null infinity through an approximate extraction , we can apply standard formulas to estimate the energy and angular momentum carried away by the gravitational waves .",
    "we continue to work with the axial perturbations , with formulas featuring only cpm and rw masterfunctions .",
    "the luminosity expressions are the following : @xcite    [ eqn : elflux ] @xmath181    in the distant wave - zone we expect @xmath182 and @xmath183 .",
    "however , sec .  [ sec : axialself ] has shown that impulsive start - up can result in violation of the axial consistency condition ( [ eqn : cpm - rw - selfconsistency ] ) , and such violation in turn results in discrepancies between the above luminosity formulas . as seen in sec .",
    "[ sec : staticmastereqn ] , whether simulations are based on @xmath159 or @xmath160 , an impulsive start - up generates a jost junk solution , even at long distances from the source . although dynamical junk is also present , its effect is negligible in the wave - zone at late times .",
    "table  [ table : circ_waveformqunt ] collects summed luminosities for @xmath184 waveforms .",
    "the top set of numbers are unaveraged and recorded at time @xmath185 , while the bottom set have been averaged between @xmath186 and @xmath187 , where @xmath188 .",
    "other parameters ( cf .  table [ table : parameters ] ) are @xmath189 , @xmath190 , @xmath101 , @xmath191 , @xmath103 , and @xmath192 . for smoothing we use @xmath57 and @xmath56 . for circular orbits",
    "we expect @xmath193 , where brackets denote time averaging for a generic luminosity @xmath194 .",
    "relative errors are computed by @xmath195 for the cpm luminosities computed with smoothing , time averaging has little effect .",
    "however , it does enhance the accuracy of the rw luminosities computed with smoothing .",
    "indeed , inspection of the bottom section of table  [ table : circ_waveformqunt ] shows that the cpm and rw entries in the @xmath196 column are in excellent agreement .",
    "relative to the true luminosity which would be recorded at null infinity , even the exact @xmath197 read off at @xmath198 would have an @xmath26 error , but here we have viewed the read - off value as the true one . because @xmath197 is unaffected by the jost junk solution , @xmath199 estimates error stemming from both the method ( here the chebyshev scheme ) and any residual dynamical junk .",
    "the other luminosities are affected by the jost junk solution ; however , as shown in the appendix , errors which stem from the jost solution decay faster than @xmath200 .",
    "therefore , these errors should be smaller than the @xmath26 errors associated with using the read - off luminosities as approximations to the ones at null infinity .",
    "@xmath196 & @xmath201 & @xmath202 + @xmath203 & @xmath204 & @xmath205 & @xmath206 + @xmath207 & @xmath208 & @xmath209 & @xmath210 + @xmath211 & @xmath212 & @xmath213 & @xmath214 + @xmath215 & @xmath216 & @xmath217 & @xmath218 + @xmath219 & @xmath204 & @xmath204 & @xmath220 + @xmath221 & @xmath222 & @xmath223 & @xmath224 + @xmath225 & @xmath226 & @xmath227 & @xmath228 + @xmath229 & @xmath230 & @xmath231 & @xmath232 +      over long times the influence of the metric perturbations on the particle orbit should significantly affect the gravitational waveform @xcite , and realistic waveform computations will therefore need to include this influence .",
    "incorporation of self - force effects constitutes one approach towards modeling this influence . because the metric perturbations are discontinuous at the particle",
    ", self - force calculations typically require a regularization technique .",
    "in the regge - wheeler gauge no regularization procedure exists for generic orbits ; however , direct field - regularization @xcite seems promising . for the restricted case of circular orbits",
    ", detweiler has shown how to directly calculate certain gauge invariant quantities in the rw gauge without regularization @xcite .",
    "detweiler s approach obtains the energy luminosity @xmath22 and angular momentum luminosity @xmath23 associated with waves escaping to null infinity and down the black hole through local self - force calculations performed at the particle , @xmath233 where the perturbation @xmath234 is reconstructed from @xmath1 and its derivatives @xcite .",
    "equations ( [ eq : el_evolve ] ) hold for each @xmath180 mode of the metric perturbation . for perturbations described by the cpm masterfuntion and with the regge - wheeler gauge ,",
    "the non - zero contributions ( for each mode ) involve @xmath235 in a source free region . here",
    "@xmath236 and @xmath237 are axial vector and tensor spherical harmonics @xcite .",
    "when numerically forming these expressions , we replace @xmath238 and @xmath239 by @xmath240 and @xmath241 . only when evaluated at the particle location will @xmath242 and @xmath243 be related to @xmath22 and @xmath23 .",
    "we now fix @xmath166 and @xmath244 to achieve a smooth start - up , run to the final time @xmath174 , and pick @xmath245 .",
    "other parameters are the same as those in sec .",
    "[ sec : axialself ] .",
    "we compute @xmath242 and @xmath243 for @xmath184 perturbations .",
    "because @xmath242 is computed with time derivatives of @xmath159 , the static jost junk solution does not impact its measurement .",
    "we therefore expect that @xmath246 however , an impulsive start - up appears to generate more dynamical junk at late times .",
    "figure [ fig : selfforceteste ] depicts @xmath242 , recorded as a time series , for both impulsive and smooth start - ups . a separate experiment based on waveform read - off near the blackhole and waveform extraction at the outer boundary determines that the energy carried away by the gravitational waves is @xmath247 .",
    "the relative errors in the left panel of fig .",
    "[ fig : selfforceteste ] are computed as @xmath248 , and are limited by the accuracy of @xmath22 .",
    "we therefore do not expect agreement beyond a relative error of @xmath249 , although clearly such error will settle to a constant value .",
    "the time series for both the impulsive and smooth start - up exhibit large oscillations which persist until about @xmath250 .",
    "however , beyond @xmath250 the impulsive start - up series shows larger oscillations .",
    "@xmath243 depends on both @xmath159 and its spatial derivative @xmath251 , whence the jost junk solution will impact its self force measurement .",
    "with smoothing , the time series plot for @xmath243 looks similar to one for @xmath242 in fig .",
    "[ fig : selfforceteste ] , and is not shown .",
    "we note that our self - force @xmath243 measurement agrees with a separate experiment which finds that the angular momentum carried away by gravitational waves is @xmath252 .",
    "figure [ fig : selfforcetestl_snap ] shows that @xmath243 is typically discontinuous at the particle for an impulsive start - up . even with an impulsive start - up , the @xmath243 measurement yields the correct value when averaged over an orbital period @xmath253 , and it is continuous across the particle ( with the correct value ) when the particle returns to its initial orbital angle .",
    "these phenomena are a consequence of the axial jost junk solution ( [ eqn : zeropsi_general ] ) . for @xmath254",
    "fixed , eq .",
    "( [ eq : el_evolve ] ) shows that @xmath255 depends linearly on @xmath1 .",
    "therefore , @xmath256 , so we can focus on @xmath257 alone .",
    "the expressions ( [ eqn : constantseqn2 ] ) for @xmath258 are linear in @xmath259 , which is in turn proportional to the conjugate of an axial vector spherical harmonic @xmath260 @xcite . motivated by this observation , we",
    " factor off \" the conjugate , writing @xmath261 , where @xmath262 is the particle s initial orbital angle and @xmath263 is a real discontinuous function solely of @xmath70 .",
    "the expression ( [ eq : el_evolve ] ) for @xmath243 involves @xmath264 , which by ( [ eq : htp_tandhtp_p ] ) is proportional to @xmath237 . in the equatorial plane @xmath265 , and we conclude that @xmath266 , where @xmath267 is a real discontinuous function solely of @xmath70 .",
    "therefore , when the particle returns to its initial position ( that is , when @xmath268 ) , the value of @xmath257 is pure imaginary and @xmath269 . for perturbations generated by a particle in circular orbit , we have seen that @xmath270 to high accuracy .",
    "combination of this expression and the above arguments for axial perturbations then gives @xmath271 when @xmath268 .",
    "moreover , one finds @xmath272 for time averaging over an orbital period @xmath253 .",
    "this section considers a particle in the eccentric orbit described in section iv.b.2 of @xcite . in the notations of that reference the orbit s eccentricity and semi - latus rectum are @xmath273 , and we choose @xmath274 and @xmath275 to fix the particle s initial position .",
    "we simulate the resulting @xmath168 perturbation with ( cf .",
    "table [ table : parameters ] ) @xmath169 , @xmath276 , @xmath171 , @xmath277 , @xmath173 , @xmath278 , and @xmath279 .",
    "we again take @xmath57 , @xmath56 as the smoothing parameters . since @xmath280",
    ", we use a coordinate transformation to keep the particle at a fixed location between subdomains ( see @xcite for details ) . before making comparisons",
    ", we first interpolate all fields onto a uniform @xmath70grid ( tortoise coordinate ) with 6063 points .    fig .",
    "[ fig : ecc_rw_cpm_metricpert ] shows the difference between fields for smooth and impulsive start - ups .",
    "the two numerical solutions are clearly different , although for the case of eccentric orbits we have no analytical understanding of the resulting  junk solution \" presumably seeded by impulsive start - up .",
    "empirically , we find that this solution satisfies    @xmath281\\!\\big]}(t ) = -   { \\big[\\!\\big[}\\psi_{\\mathrm{analytic}}{\\big]\\!\\big]}(0 ) \\\\    & { \\big[\\!\\big[}\\phi_{\\mathrm{junk } } { \\big]\\!\\big]}(t ) = 0 \\\\   & { \\big[\\!\\big[}\\pi_{\\mathrm{junk } } { \\big]\\!\\big]}(t ) = 0,\\end{aligned}\\ ] ]    where @xmath282\\!\\big]}(t ) = f_p(t)f(t , r_p(t))/(f_p^2(t)-\\dot{r}^2_p(t))$ ] in terms of @xmath283 .",
    "see @xcite for a derivation of the analytical jump . these time independent jump conditions are the same as for the circular orbit @xmath27 solution . with our choice of numerical parameters",
    "the axial consistency condition is satisfied to better than a @xmath284 relative error throughout the entire domain for a smooth start - up . for an impulsive start - up the condition",
    "is violated to the order of the solution itself .",
    "we conclude that , as for circular orbits , the junk solution generated by an impulsive start - up leads to an inconsistent modeling of the axial sector .",
    "table [ table : ecc_waveformqunt ] collects energy and angular momentum luminosities .",
    "these luminosities have been averaged from @xmath285 to @xmath286 , where @xmath287 is the radial period ( see @xcite for further details ) .",
    "unlike the circular orbit case , the discrepancy between waveforms corresponding to smoothly and impulsively started fields may be larger than usual @xmath288 error associated with read - off at a finite radial location rather than infinity .",
    "moreover , the junk solution would seem determined by the initial orbital parameters . indeed",
    ", the values @xmath201 and errors quoted in our table strongly depend upon such choices .",
    "@xmath289 & @xmath290 & @xmath291 + @xmath292 & @xmath293 & @xmath294 & @xmath295 + @xmath296 & @xmath297 & @xmath298 & @xmath299 + @xmath300 & @xmath297 & @xmath301 & @xmath302 + @xmath303 & @xmath304 & @xmath305 & @xmath306 + @xmath307 & @xmath308 & @xmath309 & @xmath310 + @xmath311 & @xmath312 & @xmath313 & @xmath314 + @xmath315 & @xmath316 & @xmath317 & @xmath318 + @xmath319 & @xmath320 & @xmath321 & @xmath322 +   +   +",
    "a number of time - domain methods exist for solving eq .",
    "( [ eq : genericwaveeq ] ) as an initial boundary value problem , including those described in @xcite .",
    "these methods vary in both the underlying numerical scheme ( e.g.  finite difference , finite element , pseudospectral , and spectral ) as well as their treatment of the distributional source terms ( e.g.  gaussian representation , analytic integration , domain matching ) .",
    "numerical simulation of metric perturbations may also involve other choices ( e.g.  gauge , number of spatial dimensions , choice of numerical variables ) .",
    "moreover , similar time - domain methods exist for solving the forced teukolsky equation describing particle - driven perturbations of the kerr geometry ( see for example refs .",
    "@xcite ) . for all of these methods ,",
    "the issue of impulsive start - up would seem pertinent , although clearly we can not examine each method .",
    "nevertheless , we now attempt to provide at least partial insight into the ubiquity of static junk solutions .    as mentioned earlier ,",
    "the results and observations of this paper have been independently confirmed with each of our two numerical methods : the nodal legendre dg and chebyshev schemes .",
    "however , as these schemes are rather similar , we now briefly consider a finite - difference scheme for solving ( [ eq : firstordersys ] ) , based on fourth , sixth , and eighth order stencils for the spatial derivatives . to stabilize sixth and eighth order stencils ,",
    "we have followed ref .",
    "furthermore , we replace the dirac delta functions in ( [ eq : firstordersys ] ) by narrow gaussians .",
    "precisely , for @xmath323 we make the replacement @xmath324 for both the @xmath325 and @xmath326 terms in ( [ eq : firstordersys ] ) .",
    "analytic expressions for @xmath325 and @xmath326 are readily computed with eq .",
    "( 28 ) from ref .  @xcite . with essentially the same experimental set - up described in subsection [ sec : staticmastereqn ]",
    ", we repeat that experiment using 4000 points and sixth order spatial differences .",
    "the results , shown in fig .  [ fig : finitedifference ] , clearly indicate the presence of a static  jost junk \" solution .",
    "a larger choice for @xmath327 gives rise to a rounder transition near the particle .",
    "however , the following shows that such contamination is not a generic feature . for circular orbits , our system ( [ eq : firstordersys ] ) becomes @xmath328 where the time - dependent jump factors are @xmath329 $ ] and @xmath330 $ ] .",
    "we introduce a variable @xmath331 obeying @xmath332\\delta ( x - x_p),\\ ] ] so that the system formally becomes @xmath333 where @xmath334 = f(t , r_p)/f_p$ ] .",
    "if we now replace the @xmath21,@xmath335 terms in the new system by appropriate gaussians , _ then we do not observe a persistent jost junk solution _ when trivial initial conditions are supplied ( neither in finite - difference nor dg simulations ) .",
    "persistent junk solutions arise from the combination of inconsistent initial data and the distributional forcing terms which define the emrb model .",
    "in particular , we observe that development of a jost junk solution depends on how the distributional forcing is treated rather than the underlying numerical method . therefore , whether or not they contaminate simulations should be considered on a case - by - case basis .",
    "domain matching approaches which enforce jump conditions without approximation ( considered in this paper ) exhibit a jost junk solution in the absence of smooth start - up . with first order variables",
    "such approaches correspond to system ( [ eq : nodeltaprime ] ) rather than ( [ eq : deltaprime ] ) .",
    "treatment of system ( [ eq : deltaprime ] ) with gaussian representations for @xmath21,@xmath335 exhibits no persistent junk solution , although such an approach necessarily introduces large method error relative to the exact distributional model and features variables with @xmath21-like behavior near the  particle \" ( gaussian peak ) .",
    "the issue of a static junk solution for schemes which discretize the second order equation ( [ eq : genericwaveeq ] ) deserves further consideration , although , if present , then the particular jost junk solution observed in this paper would likely be of relevance . or @xmath123 .",
    "such solutions will necessarily be discontinuous , and presumably such discontinuities could only  hide \" at the particle , requirements that fix the form of the static solution up to the constants @xmath112 and @xmath113 introduced in section [ sec : staticmastereqn ] . ]",
    "we have shown that impulsive starting conditions are inadequate for time - domain modeling of extreme mass ratio binaries .",
    "such conditions result in more dynamical junk , evident in self - force calculations , and potentially a static jost junk solution which persists indefinitely .",
    "although each effect is small compared to the physical solution , such systematic errors will corrupt studies which require high accuracy .",
    "for example , computation of waveforms accurate to second order in the mass ratio requires reconstruction of the first order perturbations .",
    "since these first order terms act as sources for the wave equations describing the second order masterfunctions , the presence of a jost junk solution will affect second order waveforms .",
    "circular orbits far from the massive central object ( of potential relevance for the quasi - circular phase of inspiral ) are similarly impacted by the jost junk solution .",
    "( [ eqn : constantseqn2 ] ) indicates that the magnitude of a polar - mode static junk solutions does not decay as @xmath336 becomes large ( compare with eqs .",
    "( c5a ) and ( c6e ) from @xcite ) . however , such decay is present in the axial case ( compare with ( c8a ) and ( c9c ) of @xcite ) . when studying eccentric orbits , errors arising from the persistent junk solution appear to corrupt studies requiring even modest accuracy .",
    "minimization of dynamical and jost junk by smoothing the source terms during start - up will improve waveform templates and self - force techniques with minimal computational and human effort .",
    "we thank s.  detweiler for discussions and correspondence , l.  barack for comments offered at the 12 capra meeting on radiation reaction , and c.  galley and m.  tiglio for answering our questions concerning effective field theory approaches .",
    "we gratefully acknowledge funding through nsf grant phy 0855678 to the university of new mexico and dms 0554377 and darpa / afosr fa9550 - 05 - 1 - 0108 to brown university .",

    "@xcite , and the generalized riemann scheme @xcite associated with the equation is @xmath392.\\ ] ] the notation is similar to the @xmath361-symbol , but also indicates the type of singular points in the first row ( regular singular points are indicated by a 1 ) .",
    "we find the scheme @xmath393.\\ ] ] for the specific case of the time ",
    "independent zerilli equation ( [ eq : notimezerilli ] ) .    upon transforming the ode specified by ( [ formofpq ] ) to normal form",
    ", we find the new accessory parameter @xmath394 as well as the transformed scheme @xmath395.\\ ] ] with the assumptions @xmath396 and @xmath397 , this scheme corresponds to the heun equation @xmath398 in normal form , where @xmath399 here the transformed scheme @xmath400\\ ] ] is expressed in terms of the constants @xmath401 , @xmath145 , @xmath402 , and @xmath403 which may be related to the above exponent pairs @xmath404 . the normal form of ( [ eq : notimezerilli ] ) then has the scheme @xmath405.\\ ] ]    while the preceding analysis both addresses the structure of the time - independent zerilli equation and reveals the asymptotic behavior of the solutions near any given singular point , it does not provide concrete analytical expressions for the solutions @xmath129 considered in the main text . to obtain such expressions",
    ", we use the intertwining operators @xcite @xmath406.\\ ] ] using our earlier solutions @xmath407 to the time - independent regge - wheeler equation , we then get corresponding solutions @xmath408 to ( [ eq : notimezerilli ] ) by direct application of @xmath409 and the identity @xmath410 therefore , we have also expressed the relevant polar solutions in terms of the gauss ",
    "hypergeometric function @xmath411 .",
    "the analysis above then shows that we are likewise able to express solutions to a particular instance of the heun equation in terms of hypergeometric functions .",

    "e.  w.  leaver , _ solutions to a generalized spheroidal wave equation : teukolsky s equations in general relativity , and the two - center problem in molecular quantum mechanics _ , j. math .",
    "phys .  27 ( 1986 ) 1238 - 1265 ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in the context of metric perturbation theory for non - spinning black holes , extreme mass ratio binary ( emrb ) systems are described by distributionally forced master wave equations . </S>",
    "<S> numerical solution of a master wave equation as an initial boundary value problem requires initial data . </S>",
    "<S> however , because the correct initial data for generic - orbit systems is unknown , specification of trivial initial data is a common choice , despite being inconsistent and resulting in a solution which is initially discontinuous in time . </S>",
    "<S> as is well known , this choice leads to a  burst \" of junk radiation which eventually propagates off the computational domain . </S>",
    "<S> we observe another potential consequence of trivial initial data : development of a persistent spurious solution , here referred to as the _ jost junk solution _ , which contaminates the physical solution for long times . </S>",
    "<S> this work studies the influence of both types of junk on metric perturbations , waveforms , and self - force measurements , and it demonstrates that smooth modified source terms mollify the jost solution and reduce junk radiation . </S>",
    "<S> our concluding section discusses the applicability of these observations to other numerical schemes and techniques used to solve distributionally forced master wave equations . </S>"
  ]
}
